editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The example. As it was presented by her majesty's servants at the private house in drury-lane.
London. Printed by John Norton, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. 1637.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: 'Twill be a great assize, how things will hit
For us appearing at this bar of wit.
Is most uncertain, we have named our play
The example, and for ought we know it may
Be made one, for at no time did the laws
However understood, more fright the cause
Of unbefriended posy, since the praise
Of wit, and judgement is not now adays
Owing to them that write, but he that can
Talk loud, and high, is held the witty man,
And censures finely, rules the box, and strikes
With his court nod consent to what he likes;
But this must be, nor is't our parts to grudge
Any that by their place should be a judge;
Nay, he that in the parish never was
Thought fit to be o'th jury, has a place
Here, on the bench for six pence, and dares sit,
And boast himself commissioner of wit,
Which though he want he can condemn with oaths,
As much as they that we are the purple clothes,
Robes I should say, or whom i'th Roman state
Some ill-looked stage-keepers, like lictors wait
With pipes for fasces, while another bears
Three-footed stools in stead of ivory chairs,
This is a destiny, to which we bow,
For all are innocent but the poets now,
Who suffer for their guilt of truth, and arts,
And we for only speaking of their parts.
But be it so, be judges all, and be
With our consent, but thus far take me w'ee
If any meet here, as some men i'th age
who understand no sense, but from one stage,
And over partial will entail like land
Upon heir's male all action, and command
Of voice and gesture, upon whom they love,
These, though called judges, may delinquent's prove.
But few such we hope here, to'th rest we say
Hear patiently ere you condemn the play.
'Tis not the author's confidence, to dare
Your judgements, but your calm ears to prepare,
That if for mercy you can find no room,
He prays that mildly, you pronounce his doom.

div.head: Actus. 1.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Dormant, why Dormant, thou eternal sleeper!
Who would be troubled with these lethargies about him?
Dormant, are you come dreamer.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Would I were so happy, there's less noise in a steeple upon a coronation, o sleep, sleep, though it were a dead one, would be comfortable; your worship might please to let my fellow Oldrat watch, as well as I.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Oldrat? that fellow is a drone.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: He has slept this half hour, on the iron chest, would I were in my grave to take an nap, death would do me a courtesy, I should be at rest, and hear no noise of Dormant.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nothing but a yaw sir, I do all that I can to keep myself waking.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis done considerately, this heavy dulness,
is the disease of souls, sleep in the night,?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Shall I wake my fellow Oldrat, he is refreshed

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Do, but return you with him, I have business with both.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To hear us join in our opinion, of what's o'clock , they talk of Endymion, now could I sleep three lives.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: When other men measure the hours with sleep,
Careless of what they are, and whom they trust,
Exposing their condition to danger
Of plots, I wake, and wisely think prevention,
Night was not made to snore in, but so calm
For our imaginations, to be stirring
About the world, this subtle world, this world
Of plots, and close conspiracy, there is
No faith in man, nor woman, where's this Dormant?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Here is the sleepy vermin.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: O come hither; sirrah, where's your lady?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Out all this night at play sir,

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: All night, there's some plot, but I am safe
At home, your gaming ladies are strange whirligigs,
But while she plays, and revels with the gallants,
Here I am cabled up, above their shot,
And see in my imagination all there plots,
Nay, we are the quietest couple, never meet,
No ▪ not a bed, there may be plots in that,
This part o'th house is mine, and here I walk
And see the soul, the very soul o'th world.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: It has been day this two hours.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Then 'tis time for me to go to bed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would my hour were come once.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Keep out day light, and set up a fresh taper,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: By that time we have dined, he'll have slept his first sleep.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: And after supper call for his breakfast.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: You're sure 'tis morning?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: As sure as I am sleepy —

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: And that your ladies not come in?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: As sure as I have the key.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Is my niece ready?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Two hours ago sir.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: So early? there may be a plot in that, say
Her uncle would speak with her, I use every morning,
Before I go to bed, to give her counsel,
In her husband's absence, she is young, and handsome,
And there be plots ith' world. Dormant, come hither.
What gentlemen do frequently come hither?
Who does visit her most?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My lady sir?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: My niece Jacintha sirrah, for my wife
I will let her alone of purpose yet,
To mind her game, shuffle, and cut, and dice,
And dance the brawls, they cannot cozen me.
Say my intelligence, who does visit most
My kinswoman?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The gay lords often with her.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: He that comes every morning like s. George.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I do not say to mount her, the lord —

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Fitzaverice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The same, sir he's the most bountiful gentleman and makes us all so pray for him.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: More plots, he has a vast estate, and though
Fame speak him noble, I suspect he loves her.
He has my nephew's land is mortgage too.
A mere device, I fathom it, come hither,
Let not the arras hear us, say what prank
Of mischief, has he done, he should be bountiful
To thee? on what suspicion canst deserve it?
Come be ingenious, and confess.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Who I be ingenious? alas you are deceived.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Be free, this groom conspires.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do I look like one that would be ingenious?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: What noise is than? more plots, let me enter,
They are saucy with my doors, 'tis well they are
All heart of oak, and sound to endure the knocking.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I hear my lady's footman call the porter.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I'll keep no gate that will be knocked o'this fashion
I think it were a special policy
To have a kind of a wheel; or turning engine
Advanced before my door, and admit none
Without a ticket.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: My lady is come sir,

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Is she alone?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: The gentleman that compliments with my lady,
And is here half an hour before my lord still —

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Master confident?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: The same, he mans her ladyship, and she is coming this way through the gallery.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Was ever such an impudence? she wonot carry
Him to her chamber? new plots, obscure me hangings.

div.stage: Enter master confident, and lady Plott.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I shall report how much his lordship owes
For this most noble favour,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: He deserves,
By many bounties ever to command me,
And I must thank your pains, but in my chamber,
We may discourse more freely.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You much honour me.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Bounty, and lordships, and discourse in chambers?
This fellow is a rascal, new new plots,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If your worship mean to lie with her ladyship —

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: By no means.
How happy am I, that we keep several quarters,
Some husband would torment himself with watching,
Screw his nose in at a keyhole, or in some cranny
Wedge his long ear, let 'em alone, it makes,
It makes, and my lascivious gamester find his plots discovered,
All his wit, gleaned from Italian sonnets? and loose times;
His bouncing, and his braves shall not disguise
His heart from me, I see't, I see't already,
And laugh that I am alone, and have my humour.
O, 'tis my niece, away and dress my pillow.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Morrow? 'tis now my bed time.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You were pleased.
To send for me.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I did dear niece.
Before I go to sleep, I must commend
Advices to thee, 'tis part of my devotion,
In brief, because the day comes fast upon me,
Have a great care you be not seen too public,
Your chamber's spacious enough to walk in,
There's danger in society, and the world
Is full of plots,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What plots?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I know not, but
Be solitary as I am, and be safe.
Your husband's debts have made him quit his country,
He was an unthrift, nay I spare him not
Although he were my kinsman, 'twas ill done,
Whose plot soe'er it were, to lose your jointure,
Times are necessitous, but while he drills
His men abroad, take heed you meet not hotter
Service at home, there be fine lords ith' world,
And gentlemen that run, and carry messages,
And pages, that bring jewels, and can whisper
The bawdy poesies, and so-forth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You are not; jealous of me

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Nor of my wife, I lie
Alone discreetly, let my madam play,
Sit up a nights and gambol,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And d'ye love her?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: At distance, as becomes a politic man,
That would not sell his state to buy an heir,
Our looks so seldom do converse, that if
We should engender at the eyes, she would
Not teem so often as an elephant, fool's diet with
There wives and be in danger of provocatives
To frisk, and mount the table, precious pastime!
Come thou art happy; that thy husband's absence
Hath given thee occasion to be solitary,
Trust not the air abroad by my example.
Take heed of plots, and so goodnight.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Good morrow.
I thank you for your counsel but it needs not,
I pity the condition of this gentleman,
That makes his life a penance to seem wise,
He talks of plots, and is the greatest enemy
To himself with his vain fears, but why do I
Discourse of misery without myself,
That carry in my bosom every minute,
All that can make a woman miserable?
Thought of my husband wounds me, yet I cannot
Be suffered to enjoy it, like a deer
I am chased by foreign hunters, and not left
To think what cruelty at home pursues me.
sp.stage: Enter her woman and a page.
sp.l: You might have known my pleasure, in good manners,
Ere you admitted any.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: 'Tis but a page madam, the poor child
Wants years to offend.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: He serves the lord Fitzamorous
Beshrew your diligence.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Who commends to your
Fair hand these jewels madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I prithee carry 'em back, their insid's poison,

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I would not be corrupted with the one,
To betray tother so, they cannot fright
When you examine, if you knew his lordship
So well, as I would wish, you would accept
And cherish these presentments, you're the first
Lady within my observation,
That has taken time, to ask her conscience
The meaning of a jewel, sent by a lord,
A young and handsome lord too; 'tis a thing
At court, is not in fashion, and 'twere pity
One with so good a face, should be the precedent,
Of such superfluous modesty.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Does your lord
Instruct you thus?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: We take it of ourselves,
pages and waiting women are apt by nature
To understand their office, you may be confident,
My lord means honourably, and as becomes
A gentleman of high blood, he will visit
Your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I shall not need, return him then my thanks,
By messenger.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I apprehend,
And wish you a morning fair as your own beauty,
My humblest duty.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How black sin doth scatter
Her seed betimes, and every ground is fruitful.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Has she the paper?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: And the jewel too.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: I know she'll chide me, but his lordship's
Bounty commands I should be serviceable.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Away, and wantonness inspire me, lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: More rude intrusions?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Patience noble madam,
The message that I bring, is more calm and gentle
Than the cool wind, that breathes upon the flowers
Soft kisses in the spring, the woollen feet
Of time do move with a less noise, than mine
Beneath this happy roof, vouchsafe your ear,
And words shall meet your sense, and court it with
Swifter delight than apprehension
Knows how to reach, and when I have let fall
Love, which doth make all language rich, and told you
His name that gives his life up in my breath,
To be made blessed by being yours, you'll wish
I were all voice, and to that harmony,
Chain your own soul for ever.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What do you mean
By this strange language? pray be clearer, sir,
If you direct it to my understanding.
What is your business?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have told you, madam.
Love.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What love I beseech you sir?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A love that doth include in his own flame
What poets made but fiction in the gods,
When earthly beauties tempted them from heaven,
A fire which from the bosom of love's priest
Shoots up religion and a sacrifice
To what his soul adores, a glorious love,
And love of you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Of me? it will concern
That I should know him.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Had his person been
A stranger, so much worth, and fame prefers him
To every noble knowledge, that you cannot
Be ignorant, what wonder of mankind
I point at, hath report brought to your ear
I'th stack of men, one that hath had the praise
Of wit, of valour, bounty, a fair presence,
A tongue to inchant heaven? these wait one him,
As he, to be your servant: he is a man
(What pity it is I cannot call him more)
The pride, and darling both of war, and peace,
The lord of many worlds.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: How sir! He may be bountiful indeed then.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: With your pardon,
Shall we allow to every common man
A little world, and not think him worth many,
Who hath the price of thousands in himself?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: What miracle is this?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He is a man
So full of all, that thought, or love can be
Ambitious of, that nothing can deserve him,
But she alone that hath in her own frame
Of woman, all that ever praised the sex,
And these are all your own, make him so too,
And from your loves, the decayed world shall hope
To see a race of demigods.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I find not
By all these marks of honour and of goodness
what person you commend thus

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Can there be any beside my lord?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Your lord may be
Besides himself after so great a character.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: The lord Fitzavarice.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Cry mercy sir,
I know him, and you might with half the expense
Of so much wit in blank verse, have expressed
His purpose, and himself, I thank him heartily,
But am not so much worth, pray tell him so.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Lady, I do not use to thrive so ill
In my love-undertakings.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Is't your trade?
It seems so, by your prompt and elegant way,
Are you solicitor general for other's,
In love, tied by your place, never to move
Conditions for yourself? he is but a lord
Whose fame you have advanced thus.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You're right, lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And I was never taught, that wit or handsomeness are assured by patent, d'ye think this lord
sp.l: May not find his peers?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: No question, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: This would well be a double knave.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: There may be gentlemen,
That owe no high and mighty titles, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: As gracious with a lady;

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And as active;

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: With wit, with valour, bounty, a fair presence,
And tongue to inchant heaven.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: As I would wish,
I only was ambitious to enjoy her
After my lord, if once she were corrupted?
Venus send me good luck, and I be
His taster, but he's here.
Trust me another time.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Hast prevailed?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I have taken off the impossibility,
Or she deceives me much: to her yourself,
I'll take my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Still melancholy?
What d'ye mean lady?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I have kept a jewel for your lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Will she come to't already?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And because
I would not be held guilty of ingratitude,
Not furnished with a gift worth your acceptance,
I must present your own again.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Why this
I sent you, madam, do not so dishonour me,
I have plenty of these trifles shalt have more,
Richer and brighter to attend thy beauty,
Here they will shine in their own place.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I dare not accept of any, they are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: They are not poisoned.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Yes more killing than
The teeth of serpents, or the viper's blood,
Without a charm, they had ere this undone me.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Pray make your sense familiar to me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Can you seem ignorant, by whose direction
They were sent hither, o my lord, but think,
What honour you can gain out of my ruins.
Why do you still pursue me with this heat
Of sensual flame, and send these tempters to me,
After so many vows, to keep my faith,
And name unstained?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Still in these foolish humours?
What did you marry for?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: To enjoy my husband.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Enjoy him in his absence then by proxy.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: When he is absent from my heart, may
Consent to be as black, as you would make me;
But while he hath a constant dwelling here,
I must lose both at once, if I forsake him.
O think upon yourself my lord, and make
your title good, and justify, that honour
By ourselves acquired, is richer, then what blood,
And birth can throw upon us, send no more
Agents to plead your shame, their errand is
So foul, it must infect 'em, to be false,
Even to yourself, my husband is abroad
To far from home.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: He's fighting i'th Low-countries,
By his example you may skirmish here,
A little, if you please, I do not wish him
Returned, although I have his land in mortgage,
If you would be less cruel, you may pay
His debt in other property, and cancel
The payment in due time.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'll hear no more.
You have a stayned soul.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I do love this lady,
As gentlemen now call love, and that extremely.
She is all nun's flesh about her, but has the Devil
No trick to thaw her chastity? I must have
Some way to enjoy her body for my credit,
The world takes notice I have courted her,
And if I mount her not, I lose my honour.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: So, so, now we are furnished.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Our acts and deeds are to show for't.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Sigillatum et deliberatum in praesentia notarij .
Publici. I thank you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: In the presence of the notorious publican.
But d'ye hear, who shall pay back the money?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What money?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: The money we ha' taken up to go a-wooing to
This kickshaw.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Share and share like, however , the security
is good, and the scrivener satisfied.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: I have 〈◊〉 great mind —

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: To pay it all, shalt have my voice.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Upon condition the lady would seal to
Covenants, you should find me reasonable.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: For that we must take our fates, one of
Us is sure to carry her against the world.
He that has least wit, has five hundred
Pound a year, if that, good clothes, and a
Handsome man with appurtenances, cannot
Tempt an elder sister, would she were sent
To a nunnery, let's lose no time, but advance to her instantly,

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Stay I have it, and no unhappy invention,
A device, if the worst come to the worst,
You will thank me sort.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What is't?
Mercury himself be the doctor midwife, and
Deliver thee.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: The gentlewoman we aim at, has a great
Estate, a fortune for a lord.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: All this I know.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: She has many suitors,

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: So much the worse, proceed.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: But none in grace, makes herself merry with 'em,
And jeers 'em mainly, cannot love.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What comfort is this for us?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Now I come to't, we two do love this lady,

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: No matter for that, toth' point
We come a-wooing to her.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: 'Tis not possible
We should both draw the prize, but one can be
Her husband.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Of us two, right.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: And yet in our particular,
There's none of us can say, he shall prevail,
And be the man, the man, that must be lord
Of the estate, justle the noblemen. And domineer.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What of all this?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Now mark me,
He that shall conquer this Virginian island
and write himself lord of the golden-mines,
Will have a very fine time on't.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Very likely, what's the conclusion?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Nay tell me first, what will
Become of him that must
Sit down with a willow garland, that has sealed
For a thousand pound; with what dear appetite
Shall he discharge the scrivener?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: One on's must lose, unless we could divide her.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Then I have thought a way to make us both
Gainers, in some proportion.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: That were a trick worth our learning.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Play your cards wisely, and 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: As how prithee?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Why thus
He that shall marry her of us two,
As one of us must speed, shall enter bond
At's marriage, to give the other a thousand pound,
This composition may be allowed and sealed to,
If you consider, something will be requisite,
For them, that go without the maidenhead,
Debts and devices will grow due, and sack
Will not be unnecessary, to forget her health in,
What think you on't? and whoe'er obtains the lady
Will have no cause to grumble at this motion,
Is not this equal and a certainty for both?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Let the articles be drawn, 'tis a safe bargain,
Here's my hand to't.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: A match, the writings,
Will quickly be prepared, for things must carry
Formality and law, we do but talk else,
Va withal my heart, subscribe tonight , who's this?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: 'Tis confident.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My two ingenious sparks, my landed wits,
And therefore more miraculous, what makes
Your looks exalted, as if Venus were
Propitious now?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Thou'rt right we are in love.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I knew't, I read thy character in your brow,
I see the desperate archer in each eye,
Prepared with golden shafts to wound your mistresses,
Their hearts must bleed, no destiny will help it,
You two are Cupids darlings, and he's bound
To bring you all the ladies you can wish for,
Humble and suppliant for the game.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Dost think we shall prevail then?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Have I ambition
To be your honourer, and o'th nuptial night
Light up my epithalamy, to inflame
Your bosoms, and instruct your wanton limbs
The activity of love beyond fierce Aretine.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: But dost hear! we are both suitors to one lady;
Which dost think shall carry her?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To the same lady!

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Thou knowest her,
Jacintha, lady Peregrine's sister.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The glory of her sex, you've placed your thoughts,
With a discreet ambition.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Who shall have her dost think?
Speak thy opinion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You, sir.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Shall I?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Can you appear doubtful?
Be not so much ingrate to nature's bounty,
Each part about you in silent oratory
May plead tooth Queen of love, you've to much excellence,
Were all your other graces worn in clouds,
That eye, that very eye, would charm a Lucrece,
And by the golden unresisted chains
Draw up her soul, and melt it in your bosom,
Your presence is a volume of enchantments,
But move, and every beauty falls before you,
But if you speak, which needs not to obtain,
You give a louder notice to the world,
Then when you list, you conquer, and create
One accent of your tongue, able to make
A Niobe return from her cold marble,
And spring more soft and active than the air
to court your amorous breath.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Hum no more, if thou lov'st me, we are upon
A composition, he that wins the lady
Shall give the other a thousand pound:
If you make him confident to be preferred,
He'll never sign to'th' covenant.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How preferred?
Under what misconstruction have I suffered?
Although I name it justice, he should challenge
The mistress of his thoughts, can you want merit
Who live the example of all wit, to boast
A victory in your love? were I a woman
(As nature only huddles into the world when she sends forth a man) give me licence
To express my thoughts, and had all that invention
And truth could add, to advance me to opinion,
I should be honoured to be writ your servant,
And call obedience to you, greater triumph,
Than to be empress of another world,
You have so rich a wit, that dotage may
Be justified upon't, and nothing but
A soul purged from all dregs, and quit from
Mortality, can lay a worthy claim to't.
You've put a question would afflict an oracle
To understand, and answer, which of you
Should triumph o'er a lady, I am mad
When I consider the necessity
Of fate, that one of you must be accepted,
And both so bounteously deserving. Then,
If I pronounce again that both must have her,
You'll pardon my ambition, gentlemen,
Which levels with your wishes.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Could I speak thus,
I would not thank the lady should run mad for me.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Jack prithee let's fancy him,
He has spoke home and handsomely.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Let it be five pieces, o wit of wits!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You have, gentlemen.
A care to enlarge my library, I translate
These into books, whose title-page shall own
Your name in shining capitals.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Drink, drink sack.
And divine the world with thine own wit, 'twill sell,
Hang other books, wilt never switch a play up?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Las the comedians have no soul to speak.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Nay do not leave us.
We are going to this lady, she rendezvous
Today at lady plots, we shall have music, and dancing
You'll meet my lord there

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am his creature, and your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Nay no distinction.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: What brains some men have?
I would change all my acres for his poetry.

sp.speaker: La. plot.
sp.l: Still peevish!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Most invincibly, no temptation
Can fasten on her, wood I had ne'er laid siege to her,
The taking of her province, will not be
So much advantage to me, as the bare
Removing of my siege will lose me credit.
I would she were recoverable by law,
There were some hope by vexing my estate,
And tiring Westminster, within few terms
A gentleman might come to issue with her,
If all were of her mind, what would become on's?
Lent, everlasting Lent would mortify
Our masculine concupiscence, and not leave
The strongest body worth an egg at easter.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: I am glad your lordship yet is pleasant with
Her stubborness, and were I worthy to
Advise you, it should never trouble your thoughts;
I know your lordship is not barren of acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: There be more ladies in the world,
And of the game.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: The game my lord? I hope,
You point not this at me, because I use
to pass the hours at play with ladies, and gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: At dice and cards? you have more charity,
Then to think I accuse your ladyship,
Though there be some have dared to venture both ways
Upon record, yet seem staunch to the world,
I and are thought to pray sometimes, I would not
For the Indies tempt your ladyship, I know
You are deaf to all lewd accents.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: 'Tis your goodness —

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Never to try thee, 'tis fit only such
As your cold kinswoman, wenches that have
No spirit should be tempted to those sports;
Nor is she otherwise considerable
To me, more than my charity may restore her,
I pity a handsome woman should eat chalk,
And die i'th sullens, if she might be comforted, and cured.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: With a warm bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You're right, madam,
But she's here, and her elder sister.
There is another lady I would not touch now,
I mean i'th lewd way, she has life and fire,
And moves without an engine, give me a wench,
That I must mould into a wanton shape,
And quicken her to air by my own art,
A wench that must be purged, sublimed, calcined,
By'th chemistry of love, till she become
A glorified spirit, and acknowledge
She took her exaltation from me;
In that I glory more, than to have perfected
The magisterium, and boast the elixir.
But I waste time.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: This I cannot help,
He wonot understand.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Can you work, lady,
No cure upon your sister by the example
Of your free heart?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My lord I chide her for't,
tell her what folly 'tis, to waste her health
With feeding so much melancholy, I wish
She had my constitution; to laugh
At all the world.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You are satirical.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No matter what men think of me: my lord,
I am no great admirer of their virtues.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You do not hate us, lady?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But with pardon
Of your lordship, it is possible, I may never
Run mad for love.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You do converse with us.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Because I have
As yet, no resolution to be cloistered:
Sometimes men stir my pity, but most commonly
My laughter.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You're a strange conditioned gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I would be so my lord, to all that love me,
And love myself the better, for that humour.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You'll never marry?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Certainly, not while I have any wit,
And can buy folly at a cheaper rate.
My sister has taught me; that lady has
A precious husband too, shall I, my lord,
Be bold to ask you, but one question,
What are men good for?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Pray, lady, do not fear I come a-wooing .

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your lordship's mirth offends not me in this.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Yet if I could love, I would marry thee
Of all women alive.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your lordship should
Have little cause, I hope, to wish so ill to me.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What says my lady April here, all showers?

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: My lord is a great honourer of your sister.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: 'Tis his fault in my conscience, but I hope
She'll have a care, poor soul.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Let me prepare you,
And when you see me close with madam plot,
You may advance.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Be brief.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Most noble lady.
I have no time to enlarge myself; your fat's
In danger, if discretion sit not at
The helm, with love; the gentlemen, that next
Present themselves, are not to be admitted
Guests to your bosom, in the yet dark book
Of destiny, there is a name reserved,
To make you happy, your stars guide you to
A husband, worthy of this blood, and beauty:
Think on the prophet.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Now we may come in.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Bright lady, make your humble servants proud
To kiss your white hand.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not to fast, gentlemen,
You do not mean to marry me; some air,
Or I'll go take't abroad: two to one woman?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: The lot gave me priority, you know,
Therefore obey your chance, I must first court her.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: These are the guests he talked on sure.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What shall I do now?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Fall in with the chamber-woman, that is a way
To know the ebb, and flowing of her mistress,
Sail by that wind I say.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: The truth is, lady,
I love you in the noble way of marriage.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Why my pretty mistress?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I cannot love that way.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Do you take me for a jester?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Do but name
The way you have the most mind to be loved in;
The high way, or the by way, any way,
I am at your service.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What is that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: One that would be in love too,
If he had an apprehension
You'd favour him, a thing has neither wit
Nor honesty, he would needs come along,
I could not shake him off, without a quarrel,
You'll quickly find his barrenness, and dismiss him:
He has been practising this fortnight, how
To make a leg, that learned gentleman
Knows the inside of his soul, for my own part —

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Methinks he is a very handsome man.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Should he but hear you, lady, he would think
You jeered him fearfully.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And he may have a generous mind. What's his estate?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If you do love me, give him opportunity
To tell me his poor mind a little.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: I obey.
She's taken with him, and the worst come
To the worst, there will be a thousand pound good yet.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: So resolute?

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: That man must have a powerful tongue must charm her,
Into consent of marriage, her estate
Is worth ten thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A glorious sum,
Able to whet ambition, now the others
Turn is, to show himself ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I tell you in three syllables, I love you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: That gentleman professes the same language,
Your friend.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: My friend? he's none of mine, true we have been
Acquainted, met, fell into conference of you,
And came together, lady, he is no man
Of that clear fame, to engage my serious friendship,
A very puff-fist.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What's that I pray?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: A phantom, a mere phantom.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Phantom, what's that?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: A mental typhoon, a windy caprice, I do grace him,
Or so, but he is the impudentest fellow —

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: He speaks well
Of you, gave you a worthy character.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: He cannot choose.
He knows me well enough, and all the world,
Besides I have a temper must not be
Provoked with calumnies, 'tis true he has some
Pretty parts, is held an excellent scholar, can sing,
And dance, and manage a horse well,
He's born of a good family, can speak,
When he lists, to purpose too, I confess it,
But what's all this when a man will be a rascal?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What blessed pair of customers have I got?
These would make excellent husbands, and love me
To'th purpose.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Well, remember, you have promised,
Upon condition, I dismiss you now,
To give me another answer.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My good lord,
I have an humble suit to you, I should ask
First how your hopes thrive in that sullen lady.

sp.speaker: Lo,
sp.l: I must expect, but what's your business, to me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: In brief, to advance my service to
That lady, by your honour's testimony
Of what I may deserve, I am confident
I shall reward it, by securing her
Fair sister to your wishes, she's your own,
Or if she prove too honest, I shall make
A recompense by offering to your pleasure,
The other, who by authority of your breath,
May make me lord of her, and her full fortune,
You understand, my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I do so.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Va. Your lordship's humble creatures.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I am your servant.
What shall we do, ladies? but I forget,
I have something more to say to you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: To me, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Your clients increase, lady,
That gentleman tells me, he does love you, and would marry you.
Because I have observed his nature, I'll
Give him in brief, he is a fellow will
Undo thee in a fortnight, though not in
Thy estate, yet in thy mind, a greater mischief.
If thou dost marry him, it will be policy,
To turn witch betime, ere he sell thee o'er to shame,
And so much poverty, the devil wonot
Trust thee with a familiar, now believe him,
We droop methinks —

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: So, so, here are another couple, who shall trust
Mankind? it will be a miracle to find
One honest man ith' bundle, sir, you are
Bound to my lord.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: His least favours to me
Are more than my whole life can satisfy,
O lady, if you knew him but as I do,
You would be lost in wonder of his goodness.
'Bove all, he is adorer of chaste truth,
And speaks religiously of any man.
He will not trust obscure traditions,
Or faith implicit, but concludes of things
Within his own clear knowledge what he says,
You may believe, and pawn your soul upon't.
Vouchsafe me kiss your fair hand, whose least touch
Consented to though I were old and dying,
Would quicken me into a spring.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: You forget, my lord, the music was prepared
To dance, and warm her blood.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Each take his lady

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Falstaffe I will believe thee,
There is no faith in villainous man.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Begin there.

div.stage: Enter lady Bellamia, as taking opportunity to go to her chamber, enter lady Plott, and Fitzavarice.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Follow her, my lord, she is stolen to her chamber: this will
Give you admittance through my lodgings, I'll excuse
Your absence, there be more ways to'th wood, try all.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How much you bless me, she shall want no trial,
This opportunity is worth an empire.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What shall I say? consent, dear lady, to
Be mine, and thou shalt taste more happiness,
Then woman's fierce ambition can pursue;
Shift more delights, than the warm-spring can boast
Variety of leaves, or wealthy harvest
Grain from the teeming earth. Joy shall dry all
Thy tears, and take his throne up, in thy eyes,
Where it shall sit, and bless whate'er they shine on.
The night shall sow her pleasures in thy bosom,
And morning shall rise only to salute thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Enough, too much. My lord, I hoped when last
Your importunity enforced my promise
Of other answer, I should never see you,
If being a sad prisoner to my chamber,
Might have prevented your access: but since
I am betrayed to this discourse, receive
What the necessity of fate compels to.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Another answer?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, but such an one
As must at least challenge affinity
With what I said before: not your estate,
Though multiplied to kingdoms, and those wasted
With your invention, to serve my pleasures,
Have power to bribe my life away from him,
To whose use I am bid to wear it; be yet just,
And seek no further to pollute the stream
of my chaste thoughts, I'll rather choose to die
Poor wife to Peregrine, then live a King's
Inglorious strumpet, can you think my lord,
Should I give up my freedom to your bend,
And for the pride of wealth, sell woman in me,
(For she must lose that name, that once turns whore)
Could I arrive at impudence enough
To come abroad, and not be moved to hear
My shame from every tongue, but scorn my infamy,
(As 'tis the nature of this sin to strengthen
Itself still with a greater) could you think,
If no religion can correct your wildness,
Another's price, or pleasure, would not buy me
Even from your arms? there is no faith in lust,
And she that dares be false to one she loves,
Will twine with all the world, and never blush for't,
Kiss, and betray as often. Think on this,
And call yourself home,

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Lady, I have heard you,
And do allow the excuse, I do not urge,
Although your husband's absence may plead for't,
You should be generally at my dispose,
Disclaim all place, and person, but what's mine,
I am not so ambitious, my desires
Are humble, and beg only so much favour
To admit me to one service, (You know what
To understand by it) and if you like not
My activity handsomely, discharge me again.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Worse than infection, how dare you speak
This blasphemy to honour, or I hear it?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: It's not to be avoided, I have secured
Your chamber, lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Innocence defend me.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Once more, and nature work,
You say you love your husband, and account
His absence the misfortune, that doth sit
Most heavy on your soul, this is increased
By the despair of his return; since all
hop's fled, to satisfy his deep engagements,
Which threaten ruin here, I have a mortgage
Of his, for sums lent by my thriving father,
Your jointure, (But released by you, I take it)
I am so much a servant to thy beauty,
The first night I embrace thy delicate body,
The lands thy own again, a round encouragement.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: If lords should pay so dear for every capering,
'Twould try the back of their estate: but mark me,
I ha' not done, sum up his other debts,
They swell to thousands, be but fair conditioned,
For every time thou admitst me after, to thy
Pillow, I'll strike of an hundred pound,
Till all the debts be unravelled: in the mean time
Thy husband shall return, and walk the town,
Free as an alderman, and be mace-proof,
Shall live, and lie with thee, and love thee too,
And praise thee for this noble composition,
What sayest? I find thy wisdom coming to thee.
Should it be known, who'll think the worse of thee?
Alas, good soul, 'twas pure love to thy husband,
They must imagine, wrought with thee. What woman
But would to save a husband's life, and fortune,
Venture a trifle? nay they shall commend
Thy act, and read the story to their children ▪
And envy the example was not theirs,
I shall have all the blame, but I'll endure't
For thy sake, all the tyranny will be mine,
But to secure thy peace, and do thy husband
A courtesy, I'll run a thousand hazards.
Do I appear now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, a glorious monster.
Good heaven!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Once more, will you consent?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Never o, never: let me tell you, sir,
You have so little prevailed upon my love,
That almost I forget my charity
you're a bad man: I'll sooner meet a basilisk, and be one.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Nay then. — he draws his poniard.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: If soft entreaties
With all that man can promise, move you not
To the delight, I'll snatch it from your bosom,
Nay never shake, I'll change that modest paleness
Into a blush, shall speak thy blood as hot
As mine, or leave thy veins dry as the face
Of earth, when winter hath deflowered her cheek,
And sealed up all her beauties in a frost.
Ha, madam, dead, help: I did but try thee,
My lady plot, a curse upon your plots.
Jacintha, ladies, I am undone, no help?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Peace you'll wake my master.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Help here, the lady Peregrine is dead.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If she be dead, she wonot make a noise,
Would all i'th house were dead, we should be at quiet.
Carry yourself civilly an I'll send somebody.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I shall be in for murder, o my fate!

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Alas my sister, what ha' you done, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I know not the extent of my offence,
But trust me, i le not fly passed the next chamber.
Show your best charity, o my soul is wounded.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: She returns, give her more air.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: O my poor sister, welcome to life again.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I know you both, is nobody else with you?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: No madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not my lord?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'll carry him the news of her recovery.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pray let me see him.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: He's here too soon.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Plo. Cheer up your spirit my lord, and speak to her,
she is alive, and likely.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You may come
A little nearer, if there be no change
In mind, there is in countenance, my lord,
I have had a short, but pleasing vision,
My thought from a steep precipice, as you were falling
Into the sea, an arm chained to a cloud,
Caught hold, and drew you up to heaven.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: If you dare hear me speak
Again, I dare say more, but to your ear.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I feel a new, and secure confidence.
Will you vouchsafe us favour?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: We'll not be
At to much distance.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Can there be a hope,
After so great a wrong, to find a mercy?
You must be more than woman, and you are so.
It was the error of my soul that drew
The heavy mist upon my eyes, they now
See, and admire your innocence, o madam,
I have two mighty passions within me;
Two, that are welcome, yet extremes, a joy,
To see you live, and sorrow for my trespass
Against so bright a chastity, to which,
I kneel within my heart, and ask forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If this be earnest, 'tis a heavenly language.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I feel a holy flame disperse rich heat,
About me, the corruption of my blood
Is fallen away, and of that virtue, which
A devil in me would have betrayed, I rise
A servant, and admirer, live, o live,
Thou best of wives, and practise still new wonders
Upon the heart of lust transformed men,
Until time boast, the example of thy faith
Hath purged the world, and taught us how to count
Our hours by thy miracles: I am
In love now with thy goodness, by thyself
I am, and by some rare, and unknown act,
Must make a recompense to that fair honour,
I would ha' blasted, once again forgive me,
And hide the shame, my soul does blush to think on.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This is an noble change, and speaks his nature
Not barren, when good seeds are trusted with it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: And did not mind us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am sorry,
I could have chained my ears to his discourse,
And willingly ha' grown old to have heard him:
Madam, the character of praise you gave him,
Is short of that true nobleness I find.

sp.speaker: Plo
sp.l: And yet you were not willing to believe it.
I think I know a man.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: How is this sister?
I hope you're not in earnest, though he be
A lord, as who can help, in my judgement
There are no mountains of such nobleness
As you commend his talk, if he speak not:
Another language to the ear, could never.
Ravish my understanding, though I must
Confess 'tis wild enough, I do begin
To fear you, sister.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be more charitable,
I apprehend your trouble, and shall give you
A fair account of his, and my own honour,
I could be merry now.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: Here are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My customers.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Where is my lord?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He's gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am sure he has left a heart behind with you,
Most excellent of beauties, in whose trust,
'Tis safer, and more warm, then in his bosom,
Do you not find him a brave gentleman?
He has but one fault lady, he's to modest:
But your discretion must help that that.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I honour him.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Tis well and wisely done.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pray tell me, sir,
I have heard a little trial of your wit,
Are you honest too?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Honest too?
I never did suspect your ladyship's
Breeding, and yet this question in public,
Would stagger the opinion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But you having a leading voice.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I ha' not art to help you,
Though I confess, I might o'errule some wits
O'th lower class, are you honest too?
Besides the freedom of my birth, and wealth
Of blood, I boast no overswelling fortunes,
As to what purpose, should my wits be clogged
With heavy acres, when the town's exchequer
Is mine, and every mercer is my tenant,
If he pretend to wit, and hope to justify
His shop-book, and orthography of his bills:
I would not have the scandal on my name,
To be called honest, i'th strict sense I mean,
And as it ties my blood up, for a dukedom:
But you are for my lord, and I allow it.
How thrive my gallants here?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: They cannot choose
But prosper, sir, and much the better for
Your commendations.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: You may take his opinion lady, 'tis authentic.

sp.speaker: Ia ▪
sp.l: But a little of your patience: if I found
Within me, that strong appetite to marry,
Who shall protect me from the statute gentlemen?
If it be felony to have two husbands,
I will not marry above one for certain.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Shees right for that, 'tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Cast lots.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And tie my love to chance, forbid discretion.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Choose whom you love best.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: That's to be resolved
By your demonstration, who loves me best,
For if there be, mark what I tell you, gentlemen,
But the hundred part of a grain difference,
In your affections, beshrew me, if
I choose the lightest.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Wisdom gentlemen,
And must be allowed.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Let him be the judge,
He knows us both to a scruple.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Excuse me gentlemen,
'Tis fit the lady satisfy her judgement ▪
Although I hate partiality, it becomes not
I should be here definitive, to perplex
The freedom of her choice ..

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What think you to agree among ourselves?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sure he that dares
Do most for my sake will deserve me best.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: D'ye hear that resolution, be ruled
I'll open such a path to your ambition —

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: At our next visit, you shall know us lady,

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: Nay gentlemen let's to gleek.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Command us madam.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: You and my cousin may
To the same exercise.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I would be excused
For some few minutes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: If it please you lady,
We'll pass that time at sant: did you not find
My character true of those rotten glowworms?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: You did a high favour.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You consult
Your honour in the acknowledgement, I wait you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: When will you open, sir, the book of destiny
and read the name you talk on? I am confident,
He must be master of an active soul
Whom you prefer, if I mislike his person,
I'll marry his wit, but we lose time, you'll follow.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Methinks I feel some new access of comfort,
Something that tells me, I am near a blessing,
Or else my poor heart flatters me.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: My lord commanded me present you his best service,
And with it, these: he bade me say, they are
Prologue to that reward he hath designed
Your virtue, I was glad to hear him say so,
And never went more nimbly on his message.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The mortgage? this confirms me, he is noble,
A wealthy carcanet; though I cannot merit
This bounty from him, I am rich in thank's.
But prithee tell me boy, didst not thou bring
Letters, and other jewels to me?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If I remember, you did speak another
Meaning, than what you now deliver.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Madam,
Although the narrow tie of duty bind me,
To the discharge of his commands, which it
Becomes no servant to dispute, I meet
Honest employments with more cheerfulness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou hast a modest countenance, here's to buy the
Garters, and roses.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: When I go upon
Lascivious errands, madam, I take money,
There is no other benefit belongs to 'em,
But good ones pay themselves, I am rewarded,
I shall have cause to thank you for my lord,
If he preserve this temper.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A good boy: this is not the religion of all pages.
They are a present worth acceptance,
The piety came with 'em more than doubles
Their value, if vice blush not at rewards,
there is no shame for virtue to receive them ▪
But what's all this to me, that am poor still
Without my Peregrine? who all this while
Treads the uneven path of war, and danger,
This very minute, for ought I can tell,
Wounded upon some service, or engaged,
To stand the murdering cannon, o, my blood
Grows pale within me to imagine, what
Horror attends the soldier

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Madam, madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha, my heart trembles.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir Walter Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thy looks speak comfort, what of him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He is returned.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Landed?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He's marching up the stairs, with another soldade
Tough as his jerkin, he has a tilting feather,
And looks so desperately, I fear they have
Brought home two regiments that wonot be
Cashiered without a shift.
sp.stage: Enter sir Walter Peregrine, and a captain.
sp.l: They are here already.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Oh! let me fly into his arms, my Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: My best of life!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let tears of joy salute thee,
Wellcome, ten thousand welcomes.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I embrace
Millions of bliss in thee, but let not our
Joy make us unmannerly, bestow
One welcome on my friend.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your pardon, sir,
If after many years of absence, I
Dwell long upon a husband's entertainment,
And if you think I have expressed a truth
Of joy to see him, you will easily
Believe the man, whom he calls friend, is welcome.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Madam, you honour me, it were a sin
not to be confident.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: And are we met?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Never I hope to part again, 'tis time
We now should grow together.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You'll dispense
With me for some hours, I have friends expect
At my return a visit.

sp.speaker: Sir
sp.l: I shall not
Desire you to let fall no mention
Of me, the little stay I purpose here,
You may imagine, carries danger with it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I hope you know me better.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Noblest friend.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I heard some words sound most unkindly from you,
You named a little stay, have I scarce seen
My happiness, and must be sad again
To think it will so soon be ravished from me?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Alas my poor Bellamia, I have made
No purchase but of wounds, since my departure.
I have paid some debts of war, but cannot promise
To cancel one, that threatens me at home;
What we have more than to supply our wants,
Consumes on the drum head, I was ambitious
To see thee, and this gentleman returning
With expectation to levy men
Gave me the opportunity, but I dare
Promise myself no dwelling here, scarce own
My face before a sunbeam, I must walk
I'th dark to all the world but thee, Bellamia:
But trust me, when my body is called hence
By misery of my fate, it takes not all
The soul it brought, much stays to wait on thee:
I know it would afflict thee more, to see me
A prisoner, chained to heavy debts, and shame.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thy state is not so lost, and miserable,
As 'tis presented in thy fears, look here,
And thank a providence, that smiles upon us,
This is recovered, we have some land
again, by whose revenue we may live,
And expect better fortunes, I have jewels too,
Bright ones, and rich.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: You have indeed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Possess
What I enjoy, and let us live together.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: It cannot, cannot be, alas Bellamia,
How flattering imagination would cozen us,
I am beyond sea still, in my cold tent,
Where, though my sleeps be broken with the noise
Of war, I now securely dream of thee,
And of my coming home, and talking to thee,
That thou art rich in land again and jewels,
Shadows, mere shadows: I am weary of
This dream, some charitable cannon wake me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sir you may trust your eyes, these are no forms, in airy apprehension, but the truth of things, that call you to believe, and use them as timely benefits: yet I may allow you to wonder, there's a story will deserve it.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I know not what I fear, d'ye think 'tis true then?
I will have reason for this faith, pray tell me,
How came you by this wealth, certainly I left
No sums to purchase these, more my injustice
To thee, whose plentiful estate I ruined.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A friend, a noble friend.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: That died, and gave thee
A swelling legacy, and thou hast made
This use on't to release thy desperate land,
Buy thee a carcanet, and this proud blaze
Of other jewels.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If you please to hear me,
I must declare, these are the bounty of
A living friend.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Living?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A gentleman —

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: A gentleman? forbear I am not well.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: One you are bound to honour.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Thou'st undone me,
do not, do not name him,
I know, and feel too much.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Believe me, sir,
My storey's full of innocence, and when
You have more knowledge of this friend, you'll quit
Your fears, and call him to your heart.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: My heart ▪
Is very busy, yet you may tell me
His name, to whose strange bounty I am so obliged.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: More to his virtue, though his title
Carry the shine of honour, he has a soul
More glorious; have patience but to hear me,
You will confess it, and reward his piety
With praise above a man, and be in love
With him yourself.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: In love —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The lord Fitzavarice.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Ha? the wanton lord Fitzavarice.
Thou most undone of women, did my absence
So forfeit me, or ebb of wealth corrupt
Thy giddy soul, thou couldst imagine, I
Would thank thy lust to piece up my wild ruins?
Transform me gentle heaven,
For if I be a man, and hold the knowledge
Of this dishonour, I shall do an act
Equal to this, and murder this false woman.
Have I thought life not tedious for thy sake,
And in my poverty summed up wealth enough
But in my hopes to see thee, were my winters
Not cold, when I but thought I had Bellamia,
Were all the toils, and troubles of my spring,
Not valued for this harvest? curse upon
Thy salary, were it a price to buy
All kingdoms, that the sun e'er shed a beam on,
Earned from thy body's infamy, I'd choose
To live i'th galley first, and chained to'th oar,
Give up my breath through torture. I'll to prison,
And welcome all the stings, that want of liberty,
disease, and famine, can let fall upon me,
And call thee yet more killing than all they,
Till my hard creditors forgive me in pity,
And curse thee into all I have suffered,
Wives shall accuse thy perjury, whose act
Is able to make all the truth suspected,
And virgins frighted at thy name, resolve
Never to marry, while the race of men
Curse thee, for whom they never shall spring again.
But I let passion fool me, and my tameness
May prompt thee to more sin, I'll be revenged;
But first on him, that grafted shame upon me:
It shall be thy first punishment, to see
Him bleeding, where is he? come what fine conveyances
To keep your goat close, till time play the bawd,
And secure all your ruttings? I must find him,
Appear then stain to honour, lordly devil:
Where art? Fitzavarice? Fitzavarice!
Whose reeking squire are you sir, ha my lords?
Show me straight where this fox doth earth himself,
Or I'll —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not where my lord is, but there's one a-bed .

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: A bed, expecting her, where?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But he's asleep, you'll wake him.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Show me villain quickly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O, this way, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Has misery a name beyond my suffering?
Hath love, and fortune both conspired to drop
Their stings into my bosom?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Help Dormant.

div.stage: Enter sir solitary in his shirt pursued by sir Walter.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: A plot, a plot to murder me, hold, what art?
My nephew; ha!

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: 'Tis not he, uncle you must
Excuse my compliment, he shall not fly me.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: Who goes about to fly? he did not wound me,
A naked man is soon undone, 'tis wisdom
to sleep hereafter in a shirt of mail,
When came he hither, from the Netherlands?
He is sent upon some murdering design;
But why with his sword drawn, why not a knife?
Some great man is in danger; ha! my niece weeping,
I'll sift her, Bellamia?

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.l: O my husband, sir.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Nay, than there is a plot, whom would he kill?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The lord Fitzavarice.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I knew it was some great man must be visited
Beneath the ribs, men of such vast estates
Are not long lived.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not what to do, sir,

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: He's i'th conspiracy, reveal the plot to me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My fellow Oldrat met him, sir.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Ha, more traitors.
I did suspect that fool's simplicity,
What man is to be trusted? if these men
Thrive in their first attempt, the state's in danger.
This Oldrat is a politician.
I'll stand upon my guard, entrench, and dare
The ghost of Tilly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis not very warm, sir.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Your cold considerations are best.
But I'll to bed again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: They are here, o!

div.stage: Enter sir Walter, bell: and Oldrat.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Away.
Shall we be never free from plots?

sp.speaker: Sir. Wal.
sp.l: Has he been gone this hour sayst?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Yes, and please your worship,
Would I were well gone too.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yet will you hear me, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: And trust the language of your tears? they're false,
Your gamester shall weep blood: here we untwist
Our hearts, set up o'th trade, the youth will join.
Thou mayest be still Bellamia, but not mine.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter sir Walter, and captain, as coming from a tavern.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: All's paid, and ye are welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: So; so, this tavern was well thought upon:
In my opinion, 'tis a great deal better
Than to have trusted your own passion
In such a cause, which easily might engage you
To danger, when your rage grew high, and loud.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I have obeyed your counsel: you will carry this?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I have promised you.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: And yet you must acknowledge
The wrong is greater than to be contained
Within this narrow leaf, and till I have
Revenged, it swells each minute to a volume.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My lord is noble this way, and be confident,
Will render you an account, worthy his person,
Though I am sorry to salute him first,
With a defiance.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Shalt not for all the world
Do thyself prejudice in his favour, I'll
Disengage thee again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Now you dishonour me, though he has been pleased
To use me nobly when we met at Bergen,
That must not bar the office of a gentleman
To his friend: he has been a soldier himself,
And must grant this an act of my profession.
You are certain he has done the injury?
For 't is not safe to trust suspicion,
In things of this high nature; life and honour
Must not be questioned upon naked fears,
And windy suppositions, pardon me
This plainness, you imagine I dare fight.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Shall I believe 'tis day, when I behold
The sun disperse his beams about the world?
Do I know cold, or heat, or when I thirst?
Shall I be confident we talk together?
My cause will ask the same degree of faith,
As built on equal certainty.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I urge it
No father:
Is not that he?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: 'Tis the same.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Withdraw, be careful of yourself, I'll meet you
At your uncle's house, and give you an account
Of this employment.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: She is an excellent woman,
If't be no wrong to her goodness that I spend
My childish character.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Thou'rt right, she is
Indeed boy, and shows fairer for that goodness,
I have done nothing yet to cherish her
Rare piety, or to deserve my pardon.
I'll study both.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My lord, an humble servant —

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Captain you honour me,
Welcome to England, how do all our friends
I'th Low-countries?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Happy in being your servants,

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: When landed you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: But this morning, I am fortunate
In this opportunity, my lord, to speak with you,
And to present —

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Some letters, you oblige me,
How does sir Walter Peregrine?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Well,
If please you command your boy more distance:
This paper comes from him. My lord, I should
Be guilty of much sin to your own honour,
Not to assure myself noble construction
From you, I had no thought within this hour,
To have brought more than my humble service
to your lordship, which shall still be fairly yours.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I do not like this soldad's embassage:
A challenge! some young gentlemen that have
Strong purses and faint souls, do use to fine for't,
As citizens do for sheriffs: the town swash-bucklers
Practise these feats, and live by't; but my lord
Hath beaten that opinion out of some,
It should appear, all are not yet converted.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: He appears noble, and not moved.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Are you acquainted with his discontents?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: He has imparted some, but I have no
Commission to expostulate.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I thank you,
You show yourself a gentleman, and his friend.
He shall hear from me, I had ambition
To enjoy you longer: but the terms of honour
Threaten on both sides, know me for your servant.
Pray heaven he injure not the innocent lady.
He has directed where to send to him,
And so again I thank you noble captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Your lordship's honourer.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: This came unlooked for, but I must not wave it,
O'th sudden whom shall I employ? I cannot
Want friends ambitious of these engagements:
The next I meet.

sp.speaker: Confident?
sp.l: He has professed his soul was mine,
I'll try him for his body in this action.
Yet he that is not honest, dares not fight sure.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: O master confident,
Your hopes thrive in your mistress?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Your lordship
Was pleased to advance 'em, she affects my wit,
And bold discourse, I turn and wind her soul,
She loves me infinitely.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I hope not, hark.
Be not too forward, I'm acquainted with
Her disposition, do not flatter her,
Nor seem to dote, she'll triumph then: if you
Would make all sure, be ruled by me, and slight her,
And she will court you, 'tis the trick of ladies,
If you abuse her, 'twere not much amiss.
I would not have the wench undo herself
Upon this fellow. I advise the best
And speediest way, for I expect your promise,
When she is yours, to bring us more acquainted.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Be confident my lord, good manners will
Instruct me to allow you the first fruits,
It was the fashion of our Northern princes:
And challenge it from your poor homager.
I shall be as warm the first night with her land,
And moneys. Then it seems you have no hope
To spring her sister.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Since our last salute,
Icicles hang upon my lip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My wife, for I
Dare speak her so, with smiles shall chase
That winter ▪ and shoot spring throughout your blood;
You shall not only from her lip taste cherries,
But she shall plant 'em with her amorous kiss
Upon your own, and they shall grow from thence
To tempt the Queen of love to Adonis' garden:
It shall be happiness enough for me, to watch
The hesperides, but in no dragon's shape,
That you may rifle with security
The golden orchard, I shall boast enough
By having an Elysium to serve you;
Her eyes are wealth enough to me, above
A rock of diamonds, her breath rich gums
Sweeter than those the phoenix makes her altar,
When she is her own sacrifice, and fans
The glowing pile with her grey wings; her voice
Enough for me, whose harmony would build
Up Thebes again, and make it after move,
and follow her; one touch of her soft palm
Is health enough to me, and were I old
As Aeson, would restore my active nerves,
And state my youth at thirty: I can gather
Warm snow from her fair brow, her chin, her neck,
And at my eyes drink enough immortality:
Sated with these, I'll find new appetite,
And come a wanton strawberrying to her cheeks.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: No more, you have expressed in this your faith
To me, which I am bound in honour to
Acknowledge, and without more study, have
A fit occasion to requite, and show
How near I place your love, there is a difference
Between another gentleman, and myself,
Grown to a challenge, I must answer it,
You that are so well read in books, cannot
Be ignorant of man, I'll trust my life
And honour with no second, but yourself.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: My lord I see you know me, and am blessed
The chosen man to serve you, from a troop
Of lives at your command, I should have envied
His fate, on whom else you had thrown this honour.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: So resolute? you have not seen sir Walter Peregrine,
He's returned.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I hear some whisper —

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I have named my enemy, the defiance comes from him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He's jealous of his wife, good gentleman,
And would be a cuckold upon record.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Call on me
An hour hence, I'll be at home, and use
Your friendship for the burden of an answer.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I shall think time hath lost his wings till then.
He put me to it cunningly, but his
Discovery relieved me, though I make
A noise i'th town, and am admired for bouncing,
I am cool enough i'th dog-days: my lords scrivener.
Fortune presents him to my with, the man
of all world most useful to my purpose.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Master confident, rapture your most humble servant —

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: When saw you the squire's vainman, and pumicestone?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Not since I procured 'em a thousand pound,

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Now you put me in mind of debts, has not
Sir Walter Peregrine a name within
Some list of yours? has he no creditors
By your acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: I beseech you do not
Vex me with his remembrance. I have paid
Some moneys for him, he has other friends
That would be glad to embrace him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Sure he would not
Be such a traitor not to secure thee.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Would I could reach him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Why he is returned,
Within this four and twenty hours, you may
Salute him too. Alas, a sum may be
The ruin of thy fortunes, could he have
So little charity?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: I would show
As much to him, if I could set my fangs on him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I have ever wished thee well, and if thou dar'st
Be secret, I'll direct thee to recover him,
I cannot say the debt; may be, the knight
Is poor still.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Hang him, master confident,
It will refresh my heart to be revenged;
Some say men's blood, I say their bones are sweetest.
I'd make him an example, I'll not tell
My shirt on't, how honest master confident?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Fate dotes upon thee, he, the very he,
Be artful, I'll salute him, and delay
His pace with some discourse, whilst you
Fetch shoulder-clappers, noble sir Walter Peregrine,
I feel a springtide in my heart of joy,
Swell to congratulate your safe return,
the town has drooped for your society.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: You are still the eligant time wit, I am happy
To witness both your brain, and body flourish.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What news abroad? all expectation
Is fixed upon this summer's war, we breathe
Nothing but German air, although the chance
Of war be uncertain, you can tell which hand
Is fortunate, how ha' the dice run hitherto?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: There's not much won, or lost.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: No towns of note
Taken? no convoys of provision
Cut off?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Sir you are inquisitive, as if
You would turn Gallobelgicus, I am
On some affairs now, that importune their
Dispatch, my stay being short I must attend them.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Nay prithee knight be courteous, 'tis an age
Since we conversed, is't true what loved fame scatters
Of the great general's revolt?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: We have
But the relation.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He is slain for certain.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: There was an execution.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And what treasure
Was taken by the enemy? they talk
Of millions.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Enough to keep the eagle
In a good diet. I beseech you pardon me,
We shall hereafter meet, and ha' more freedom
To enlarge ourselves, and when you have my particulars,
I will be bold to inquire in the exchange
Your news at home.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I observe trouble in you,
I hope you're in no danger.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: If you'll give me
The liberty of a subject, and allow me
The King's high way, I shall have less suspicion,
You wonot pay my debts.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I beg your pardon,
Pray do not wound my service to you with
A jealous thought, I wonot for the world
Engage you another minute.
Now for the bloodhounds.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Sir, we arrest you

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Is the mischief fallen?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Your sword shall keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: 'Tis at my suit.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Thine?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: I do but lead the dance to twenty more.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Hear me, what's your demand? let me not go
To prison.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: An action of a thousand pound more,
For the lord Fitzavarice.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Ha? than I am betrayed, that lord's a villain,
That I could reach his heart; release my body
But for two hours, my soul be forfeited
For ever, if I render not myself
Your honest prisoner.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: That were a pretty jest.
Look to your charge.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Here is a duel taken up discreetly.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Black Jew, base lord, damned villain.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: They can tame you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why look you gentlemen, I'll not puzzle you
To find out dangers, famine, fire, and sword,
Or desperate things.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Trifles for thy sweet sake.

sp.speaker: P●s.
sp.l: I would not wish you, upon easy terms.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: To prevent these, I have thought a way myself,
And with less cost, to try you, I have made
A vow I wonot marry these six months,
During which time, if you dare for my sake
Visit me every day, and never speak to me,
Nor in my company to any other —

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: How lady?
Shall I not answer any gentleman
Or lady, that shall put a question to me?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: You will give me leave to answer you,
If you should ask me any thing.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not a syllable,
Though I desired to know what o'clock 'tis,
There's your obedience, at six months end
I may reward your silence.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: She'll make him the dumb knight.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I wonot engage you to be a mute
So long, you shall be allowed to speak, and see me.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: You are noble lady.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But with this condition,
That whatsoever I entreat you say
Or do, you put in act the contrary
The very contrary, you understand me.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: How's this? if you command me to affect you,
What can I do?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I wonot be so cruel.
If these conditions please, you may proceed.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: But hark you lady, I may laugh before you,
And in your absence have the liberty
To use my tongue.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What else, sir.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: And when must I begin to mum.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Another word,
If we be just to your commands, dear lady,
At six months end, how shall we both be satisfied?
You have forgotten the statute.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: He that shall
Express most care to do his penance for me,
Must be the man, I say no more, imagine.
My lord Fizavarice.
Now begins your trial.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How fares your virtuous sister lady Peregrine?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: That gentleman can tell you.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: He tell me?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes, he had a message to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Sir you much honour me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Nay, let him know't, here have been turns my lord,
Since you were here.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Is she in health; you do not mock me?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If you love me, tell him the whole story, prithee,
For my sake.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: How she jeers him.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Pox on your subtle shoulders, are you drunk?
If I shall think you jeer me, be still silent,
I'll make you speak.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

div.stage: He kicks him, vain. Exit shaking his head, and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: At his folly my noble lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: 'Tis well you do, sir, what's your meaning lady?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: You shall know presently, if you entreat
That gentleman to stay.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: He is not going.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But your commands upon him will make sure.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Let me entreat you not to leave me, sir.

sp.speaker: Pu.
