sp.l: I leave you my noble lord? if every sand
Within my glass, were a long life, I should
Employ 'em all in waiting on your lordship.
And think the time were poor, and short to serve you
I leave you my good lord? I'm not about it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Pray, sir, stay.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Your lordship's humble servant, some affairs
Press my departure.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You'll not mock me, sir?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: You shall stay.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Lady I am gone, my lord, I must beseech
Your pardon, for the world, I dare not slip
A minute:

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Then go, you may go.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Not for a kingdom lady, I will stay,
And grow here for your service.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How came these gentlemen by these strange humours?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'll tell you, sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir solitary plot, your husband and my worthy lord and master, commends his service to your lordship, and prays you would please to accommodate him, with your coach.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: This fellow's infected too with serious folly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Towards midnight he does purpose to take the air,
And make some visits.

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: Visits and air at midnight? pray return
My lord ambassador to sir solitary,
I will give order when I go to bed,
To have the coach made ready for his progress.
Stay, I have a great desire to see his worship,
Has he the same complexion still? I prithee
Leave of thy gravity, and answer me,
Is he in bed?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No madam, a most strange
Disaster broke his sleep, and we shall be
At counsel presently, do not I talk
Already like a statesman?

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: It shall be so, come nearer.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: This your device: 'tis pleasant and pursue it,
Your sister —

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: Be you sure, and secure, Jacintha you must
With me.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Whether?

sp.speaker: Plo.
sp.l: To my husband's chamber.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Madam, your husband is returned I hear.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I hope you have not met.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Why noble madam?
sp.stage: Enter vain-man as peeping if my lord were gone, and beckons to pumicestone.
sp.l: We shall be friends if you have mercy, to
Forgive what's past, my soul shall not deserve
his ill opinion, I hope all is well between you two.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No hearts did ever meet
More loving lie, until he saw —

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What, madam?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The presents that you sent me.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: It was my fear.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Servant.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My dumb knight too, we shall have the more mirth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Would I had been poor still, although you bring
All innocent thoughts. My lord, I must beseech you,
Never to see me again, o never, sir,
It will be dangerous to express your virtue,
And every minute you stay here, is fatal,
Alas I fear he's come.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: My lord, I have been active,
And all my bodies in a bath to find you.

sp.speaker: Sir
sp.l: Walter Peregrine is arrested.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O misery of miseries!

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Look to your mistress.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Her ladyship's pardon, I observed not her
So near. 'tis very certain.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I suspect
This knave, alas poor gentleman, and yet
'Tis no misfortune to me, things considered:
Now he is safe, and I may walk securely;
In prison let him lie and cool his valour.
I shall be in charity with the tribe of varlets,
For this good turn, this taking him i'th nick,
And owe the wretch a sum, for being so fortunate
To set the mastiffs on him, I owe thee too,
For thy good news, come confident.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: To my ambition.
D'ye hear my lord, the good news is not all
You owe me for, I knew it would be grateful;
You owe me for the act, it was my wit
Betrayed him to the arrest, held him in prate
Whilst the honest knave your scrivener fetched the vultures
with fangs keen as the devils.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How I am bound to thee?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I knew was necessary. Every man
That vows his service, has not that extent
Of brain to bring about these fine things for you.
What think you of the ma'mosel, his wife now?
You have no opportunity, no power
To humble her proud body, while her husband
Sets up a frippery with his gay wardrobe;
Grows into new acquaintance with diseases,
And comfortable vermin; breaks stone walls
To show the proverb, and his hunger mighty;
Curses his stars, and learns to cant, and praise
The steam of ale, with an unchristian tossed in't;
Doth reverence Barmudas, and the ghost
Of cheese, with the Egyptian idol onions,
And crusts to break an elephant's tooth. All this
I ha' done for you, my good lord,

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: For which
I must pronounce thee a rascal; sordid wretch,
Was this your act for me? curse on thy soul for't,
My honour bleeds to death, see me no more.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You are come in a good time, sir.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Are you so cunning my young lord, I must make my lady
Sure, ere he talk, and tell her this; 'tis not '
The constitution of every lord
To take unkindly when a man compounds
A duel for him, if I be driven to't
I can forswear't again. Let valiant fools
Brag of their souls no matter what they say,
A coward dares in ill, do more than they.

div.stage: Enter sir Walter Peregrine, captain, and under-sheriffe.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: 'Tis all the favour I could show him, sir,
To make my house his prison.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: 'Tis but hell, one story higher.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You must arm yourself
with noble fortitude, passion but unmans us,
And makes us less for bearing.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Dost think friend,
The sense of all my debts could shake me thus?
I knew 'twould come, and in my fears examined
The mischief they present, 'tis not their weight
Affrights me, let the vultures whet their talons,
And creditors, with hearts more stubborn, than
The mettle they adore, double their malice,
Had I a pile of debts upon me, more
Heavy than all the world, it could, but with
The pressure keep this piece of earth beneath 'em,
My soul would be at large, and feel no burden;
That which I count my torture, exceeds all
That yet has been in mention. At a time,
Almost the very minute, when my hopes
Were ripe to punish him, and revenge had mounted
Her steely arm whose fall had crushed the soul
Of my fame's ravisher, to be snatched up
By a whirlwind thus, disarmed of all my hopes,
My hands bound up, not able to relieve
My bleeding honour: this, this murders me.
And that all this should be his cursed plot,
That gave me my first wound.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: D'ye think my lord
Can show himself so dishonourable?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Can lords
Be cowards? dost not appear, when I am pursued
By his own bloodhounds? has he not laid on me
(And what may not by this example follow
To sink me to a dungeon) all the debts
I owe him? nay is it not clear, he practises
Intelligence abroad, provoking others
To lay their sums upon me, that I may
Consume a prisoner, and assure his lust
More scope to revel with my adulterous madam,
My wife whose name is torment to my heart,
'Bove all the engines meant to wound mankind ▪
O woman, that hast forfeited the glory ▪
of thy creation, and become man's ruin.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: This is a circumstance I confess, but yet
Cannot make me conclude my lord so ignoble:
I know he had a wanton pile of flesh,
But a more noble soul, than to betray
His enemy so basely.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Is't not mischief
Enough to feel the cruelty of a prisoner,
But that black fiend must persecute my eyesight
Th'adopted son of Lucifer?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: I have a letter from a noble friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Carry it to hell.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: Correct your passion,
And leave your understanding free, to know
Your happiness, this man howe'er your rage
Let fly at him, will deserve better character,
When he appears the means of your enlargement.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: How master sheriff?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: He means of my enlargement?
Take heed how you do mock me, sir.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: Your sword —
You're free again, each particle of a debt discharged.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: Not a fee left unsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I am in a wilderness.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: You may come out when you please, if your worship
Will be at leisure to peruse this paper,
There is his name, hath been at all this charge,
Who has commanded me to ask your pardon,
And on my knees I beg it, I am undone else,
For ever with his lordship.

sp.speaker: Sir. Captain
sp.l: Lord Fitzavarice?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: It was without his knowledge, master confident
Charmed me into it, the devil did assist.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The devil?

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Yes, we three, I am sorry for it,
And if your worship have occasion
to use a hundred pieces more, I have 'em
Ready at your service, pray entreat him to
Accept it, I expect no scribbling for it,
Nor use, nor principal, nor his word; but to
My lord, that I may be the driver still of all his moneys.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I was confident, and long since cleared his lordship
In my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Was there ever such a thing in nature?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You must take the man's benevolence,
He is undone else, come there is no harm in't.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: If they be not weight, I'll change 'em.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: I humbly thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I am all wonder.
sp.stage: Reads, when you find all things fairly discharged, though you acquit not me, be pleased to continue a voluntary prisoner for some few minutes, there is necessity we should discourse, and conclude something else for both our honours.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You must pronounce him innocent, had he
Been coward, as you thought him, at least charge
He might ha' saved his honour, and secured your absence.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I begin to be a shamed,
And my suspicion cowardly falls off;
Yet certainly all this proceeds not from
Devotion to me, it is a bounty
He looks my wife should thank him for, ha?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Now I see all are your empty jealousies,
But think and be convinced, were his thoughts foul
As you imagine to your lady, it
Had been ridiculous to set you at liberty,
The only bar to his design, lust is not
So tame, and foolish, common policy
Would have instructed him to have let you rather
Languish, and rot in prison, be collected,
And think whom your false fears have injured,
A noble wife and friend.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I am too blame,
This act hath made me understand two souls.
I'll take 'em both to mine, and ask forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Your lady.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Forgive me my Bellamia,
Thou appearest white again, and only I
Black with my false suspicions of thy goodness,
My lord has given me a satisfaction
Large as his virtue, welcome to my bosom,
My best, my chaste Bellamia.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: This is joy
Able to drown my poor heart, but is all
This peace concluded?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Thus again confirmed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Just heaven hath heard my prayers, happy Bellamia.
What riches I embrace, what worlds of treasures,
In every kiss, how many lives I take
From those sweet smiles?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Who could suspect this lady?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But I am lost again, in what place am I?
Is't not a prison? o that sad thought shoots
A trembling through me.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: All is cured again.

sp.speaker: Bellamia
sp.l: I am free too, out of debt,
Nay I did wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Wast not a brave physician, that could cure
Two such distempers, when my soul, and fortune
Lay gasping, to recover both? 'tis done,
Done by thy friend, and mine, that honest lord
Hath paid all, to the scruple of a fee,
What thanks shall we both pay him my Bellamia?
Can he hath done this miracle, allow
A place for lust within him? 'tis impossible.
But he is coming hither, stay not thou,
It will require more leisure to express
Thy gratitude, return, and tell thy friends
The wonder first, that when I shall present
His person next, they may have spacious souls,
To admire and entertain him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I obey you,
Do not allay this unexpected joy
With a sad change good heaven.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You will expect him.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Religiously, an age I'll wait for him,
I prithee stay, and witness with what cheerfulness
I'll ask his pardon.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: He is come.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: My lord,
As you have made me object of your mercy,
By such an act of bounty, as no times
Have gloried in, and in that shown the clearness
Of your brave soul, uncapable of stain,
Still let it shine with charity, and make
Me confident of pardon, for an injury
I blush, and dare bleed for, to show repentance.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Are you then satisfied?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I am my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I was bold, but with no purpose to disparage
Your credit, to discharge some trifling debts.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: They were great, my lord, and must enlarge my acknowledgement,
You have obliged two lives to pray for you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And the whole age to admire.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You would encourage me.
One word, your honour's safe again.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: And happy.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Mine suffers, 'tis but young and growing on me,
It bleeds by your suspicion, I was bound
To this expense, 'tis a malicious world,
And men are apt to imagine, I was glad
You were in prison, to preserve my skin
With some excuse, this brand must not come near
My forehead, though your sea be calm, I would not
Have my fame lost i'th tempest of men's tongues,
I have made no reply, in point of man,
To your challenge, and the noise may be dispersed,
Nor will what you are pleased to accept, render
Me less unquestioned, but beget men's fears
At a high rate I have bribed your patience
basely, perhaps, their impudence will reach
To say, I have bought my passage to your lady,
And your consent to'th shame,

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I will proclaim you
Noble to all the world, and my preserver.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: There's nothing but your sword can do me right,
We shall not trouble seconds, if you please
The captain stand for both, he is a gentleman
Known truly valiant, which implies he cannot
Deceive where he is trusted, I'll expect,
You'll follow as you are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: He seems troubled. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Didst think it possible so fair a sky
Should be delivered of a tempest?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I'll tell thee as we walk, thou must not leave us.
That man is miserably compelled, that must,
To save his fame, be to himself unjust.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter sir solitary, Dormant, and Oldrat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The coach will be made ready.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: So, so, let's think and talk of something else:
Time's precious, let's talk wisely, 'twill concern us,
My brain is not in tune about my nephew,
Who knows upon what plot he is sent hither,
The Dutch are grand projectors, let's examine
Where he is gone now.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My opinion is, to kill somebody , or other.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: That would be known, and yet I heard a buzz,
Some noble man was aimed at, we were best
Say nothing, and discover him to the state,
We may be else in danger, and made accessaries
To the parricide, which is not as the vulgar
Interpret, killing of a father, but
Parem cedendo, killing of a peer,
A peer o'th land, mark that.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I understand a procedendo
Well enough, but who shall serve the writ?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Under your pardon, how can
You prove he is a murderer, let him first kill
Somebody , no matter who it be, and than you may
Discover him with a safe conscience.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Laughs.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I am of an opinion under correction that if we
Should discover him, we should not carry it so
Privately, but it would be known, and then we shall
Be in as much danger o'th tother side for concealing it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Laughs —

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now I think better on't, it cannot be concealed
Under your favour fellow Oldrat, for if we do not
Discover, the state will not be so wise, as we are,
And then 'twere pity o'their lives, besides
If he go on to kill whom he list, and nobody hear on't
He may undo the town by degrees in a moment,
And neither we nor any that is hurt, the wiser for't.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Laughs again.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Who is it laughs?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Not I, sir, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nor I, sir, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Stand both before me, is there not some spirit
I'th room? has not some conjurer a plot upon me?
Cato was wise, and never laughed, but when
Out of his casement, he beheld an ass
Eat thistles, where's the may-game? will none answer?
Sure they did laugh at me, but I'll prevent 'em,
And vex their spleens, away. I wonot trust
A laughing wizard, there's a killing face
Behind it, o the juggling of the world!
Am I ridiculous at home? there is
Some plot in agitation. I smell a rat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If please you, sir, there is a dumb ambassador desires to
Speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: A dumb ambassador?
When does he look for audience? of what nation?
Where in the map is Dumbland? I should much
Affect that country, let him have access.
I understand you are a dumb ambassador;
Your business pray with me: you are no lawyer,
Nor no divine I take it, are there no women
Non magpies in your country?

div.stage: Vain-man makes signs, and salutes him.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: This fellow must have a rare understanding,
For nature recompenseth the defects
Of one part, with redundance in another:
Blind men have excellent memories, and the tongue
Thus indisposed, there's treasure in the intellect:
Yet there may be a plot, he's sent to observe me,
A state spy, but I'll cozen his intelligence,
And be as dumb as he.

div.stage: They make signs one to another.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: I am his interpreter.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: O then first answer me, how came he dumb?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: With melancholy , sir, he has a strange
Humour to cross the method of the world.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: As how, sir? pray be plain.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Why; sir, to make
The night his time for study, talk, or business,
And never go to bed but in the morning.
But keep this to yourself, for 'tis a secret.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Study? what did he study pray o'th nights?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Why plots, nothing but plots: he did suspect
All mankind, nay their shadows in the hangings,
If they but laid their heads together, were
Dangerous, and talked treason, such a fool,
A serious fool was never before extant.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: How does my solitary uncle?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Ha cousin, forbear, we are engaged upon
Affairs of weight, that's an ambassador.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What language does he speak?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: None, none; but this is his interpreter.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Interpreter, and yet he speaks no language.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: He'll overhear you, 'tis a dumb ambassador.
I pray be gone, you are a woman, go.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And can you get no other company
Then dumb and mad-folks?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Who is mad?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: That gentleman.
Be you but master of some sense a while,
I'll make't appear he has none. Come forward, sir,
Do you observe his motion? I entreat
He should come forward, and he plays the crab.
Stand still, sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: With your pardon
I must be in action, it does stir my blood,
Which would congeal through cold else in my veins.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If it be beneficial to your body
Practise this motion still.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis very strange;
He now appears a statue:
Are they not both mad? do you think Jacintha
They have no plot in this, how came they thus distracted?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: This grew mad with catching cold
A-bed , and lying from his wife.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Cold causes are very dangerous.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: You are something guilty on't.

sp.speaker: La. Pl.
sp.l: What if my husband be asleep?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: We'll wake him.

sp.speaker: Old
sp.p: Good madam be not troublesome, do not you know who I am? I charge you to resist us, come your ways, where; where be these traitors? let me see, where is sir solitary? I thought he would ha' shown more wit than to conceal traitors in his house.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Traitors?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Traitors, we look for, and traitors we will have,
And they be above ground.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I saw two suspicious persons come into the house with my
own eyes, and they must out, there they are, I'll take
My oath master Constable.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Master Vaineman, and master pumicestone you two suspected
For traitors, o the rotten hearts of men!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Reprehend them. Your good knight must go too, go cheerfully 'twill be the better for you, if you discharge an honest conscience, you may have the favour to hang tell you be dead.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Did ever any man was sure o'th gallows, shake so?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: This fright may work some good effect upon him,
Many men have been frighted from their wits,
Having none left, why is't not possible
He should be frighted back again into 'em?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: One word I beseech you, 'tis time to speak.

sp.speaker: La. Pl.
sp.l: I hope you did not mean this for his cure,
I am not so weary cozen of my freedom.
He that's full master of his reason, may
Be master of his wife too, which I like not.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My uncle, sister, madam. Sir ha more plots?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What's the news sister? you look pleasantly.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Your face is full of sunshine madam.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Bless me, but what are these?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: We are subjects of command, she'll discover us.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Men? apprehended? what new fears invade me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What shall we do now?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: E'en what you please.

sp.speaker: Per,
sp.l: Why this is Dormant your servant uncle.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Who would ha' thought it?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And your name Oldrat, what's the matter gentlemen?
Ha you an interlude?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: If they be no officers, we can be no traitors.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Twas mistress Jacintah's plot, we did but act it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I was desirous of a scene of mirth,
How far we should ha' driven it, I know not,
Just so ridiculous are all your plots uncle, ha, ha.
You had your parts my brace of learned gentlemen,
Whom I do discharge from fear and further penance.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Make not yourself the general derision,
Your drudge's mirth.

sp.speaker: La. Pl.
sp.l: Nay, let him have his humour.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If you have still ambition to be laughed at,
And think it possible I can love such motleyes,
Come thus a-wooing every day, I shall find
Some trick at last to make your worships famous.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What think you o'this?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: One of us is sure to carry her, what think you o'th device, and the worst come to the worst, for the thousand pound?

sp.speaker: Va,
sp.l: We must agree, pay it, and be revenged.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: Do not you think you have undone us now,
And that we shall despair, and drown ourselves,
Or slip out of the world in a clean halter?
No, we will live to vex thee, for my part
Because thou gavest me liberty to speak,
To show I scorn to obey thee, and in malice
To thy injunction, I will never speak
Again, to any woman, in revenge,
I'll be more dumb than he was.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: And because.
Thou didst enjoin me silence, from henceforth
I'll practise talk to weary all thy sex.
I will be all, the everlasting talker,
And rail upon all women, till I have worn
My tongue toth' root, I'll study presently
A satire that shall eat thee through the bones,
And send thee first to an hospital.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I see I am a fool, a melancholy
Suspicious fool, and all my plots are nothing.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Let's follow, and either make him mad outright,
Or bring it to a cure, your part's not done yet.

sp.speaker: La. Pl.
sp.l: This will undo me, now must I to prison.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What dost thou think they mean Oldrat?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I think? I hope they mean well.
And lovingly, and let us like honest servants
Into the cellar and pray for 'em.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A match.

div.stage: Enter lord, sir Walter, and captain.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: Then nothing will prevail but we must fight?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: And no place more convenient, draw sir Walter,
And captain, now indifferent friend to both,
For I have no suspicion thou canst slain
Thyself by partiality, witness with
The heart I bring, I have no thought so black,
As murder, or revenge, but to preserve
My honour, which no balm can cure, if once
But the suspect of coward fall upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir
sp.l: I am not so unjust my lord to doubt your courage.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You have given proof my lord abroad,
That you dare fight.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Though I affect no glory
From actions of this nature, yet the world
At home must be convinced, our fame is lost else:
Had Peregrine been coward, or not known
For valour, I had run less hazard of
My fame, by being silent, but as I am
Beneath him in opinion, a young man
Circled with expectation of something,
That must declare me worthy of a name,
And love of men, I must attempt this danger:
But let me tell thee this, which perhaps may
Render thy sword more fatal to me, I
Did love thy lady with a sinful purpose,
Pursued ever persecuted her chaste soul,
To satisfy my wantonness, but found
An innocence so rich in her, as may
Alone excuse the ill of all her sex,
Nor has the goodness only the effect
To preserve her, but it returned my eyes
With so much shame upon myself, that I
Threw off my lust, and doted on her virtue,
Heaven shut his mercy up if I dissemble,
This injust obligation to cherish,
I did reward with trifles, which perhaps
Gave fuel to your jealousy, but know
I have designed a larger recompense,
Which your sword may confirm to her in few minutes,
for if I chance fall by it, she is declared
The heir to my estate, and she deserves it,
Which she'll employ no question to assure
Your peace, and pardon for my death, come on, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I am more lost than ever, let my wonder
Be past, or you will fight against a man
Whose soul's a great way off. Didst hear this captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: With pardon of your lordship, since you have
Declared so freely, what I think wins credit
With him too, your intentions to his lady:
There is no cause, you should engage your bloods, to any loss

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: You are my preserver, sir,
Make me not so ingrateful to advance
My sword against your life, that gave me all
The benefit of mine, I have assurance
Enough of you, and my wife's honour.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: There's
A purse of gold is troublesome, it may
Be useful to'th survivor, come, sir, fight
By thy own ladies virtue, I shall else provoke you rudely.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: For her sake my lord, we should be friends.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: That wonot help my fame,
Nor yours, if you regard what threatens it,
I must not live upon the charity
Of people's tongues, their justice shall acknowledge
I do not fear to bleed, let it be argument
To inflame thee, that thou mayest be happier
Upon my loss, since my last minute gives
Thy wife possession of all my fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: That rather charms me from each violence.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: This must compel you then, till now I never
Thought thee ingrateful, by thy fame I charge thee,
By thy Bellamia's love, fight not with pity,
Let me be worthy at least to fall with honour,
Fight so, as howsoever fate determine,
I may get honour, though in death, and not
Suffer without a wound.
So here's some blood yet.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I did but imitate my lord your character,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Blood of both sides, nay then I interpose,
As you are gentlemen, for other titles
Weigh nothing here, be just to both your honours,
You have done well, exceeding well, unless
I shall conclude there's malice on one side,
Be yourselves now, and on such noble terms
Be reconciled again, sir Walter is
No enemy at heart, and the world must
Be satisfied my lord, in your just valour,
Think what blessed providence has marked you both
For noble ends.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: I'll trust him with my sword,
Which rather shall make next impression here,
Then be his danger.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I am overcome, take me thy captive.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: My most honoured friend.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: So, so, 'tis fair on both sides, but my lord,
You bleed much, can you spare it.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Well enough, I'll wait upon you home.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: First have a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What for a scratch? let me present thee safe,
To thy Bellamia, she but with a smile
Can cure all wounds, come captain.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: We both wait on you.

div.stage: Exeunt ▪ enter Jacintha, and lady Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: You tell me wonders.

sp.speaker: Bael,
sp.l: I shall much repent
My discourse to thee, if it did not raise
Thy admiration, 'tis a noble lord,
Thou art bound to make him restitution.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Of fame, you were jealous of our honours.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I have read the chronicles, but never met
With a young lord has done the like.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To what
Virtue in time will he grow to Jacintha?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Virtue? there's another thing, not usual
In men of his rank, I allow a gentleman
to pay his own debts, but another man's,
Vows a record, besides all this, to love
Another man's wife, a handsome woman too,
And be at cost to keep her honest? miracles.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What joys flow in my heart. Thou art sad sister.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No sadness, but I have another passion, that troubles me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You'll be in time converted,
And leave your wild invectives against men,
'Tis possible you may marry, if you could
Find such another man to be your husband.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No, I wood not.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Find such another man to be my husband.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou wouldst have him, how now my witty sister?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: It cannot be concealed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Has little Cupid
Been practising with his bird-bolt, if thou beest not,
I'll wish thee heartily in love, to punish
Thy want of charity against all men
And marriage, 'tis but justice, nay be not melancholy;
He will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: He shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He shall.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Be very welcome hither, he once said
If I remember well, could he but love,
He would marry me of all women alive.
My fortune's not to be despised, however
My heart is rich enough, but it shall languish
To death, ere I will tell him so.

div.stage: Enter lord, sir walter, and captain.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But dost love him
Indeed? now but for pity I could laugh.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: You may triumph sister, you have cause.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And thou canst have no argument to despair,
Come shall I tell my lord?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: That thou lovest him.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Do him not so much injury, my passion
Can still walk in disguise, though I confess
Since your relation, 'tis become more troublesome
To be confined, o love! I never thought
to have felt thy sting, I dare not stay to see him;
I shall betray myself with many blushes:
Farewell my lord Fitzavarice.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Not so
He'll rather meet a welcome to his bosoms,
Repent not lady, you're but lovingly
Betrayed, and 'tis my happiness, I should
Have pleaded at this bar, in this prevention
I am doubly blessed, be constant, and divide
With me both heart, and fortunes: thou must needs
Be excellently good in being her sister.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I must confess my lord, I honour you.
But not for any titles, although some
Woman may be allowed the ambition,
But for your noble nature.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I am confirmed.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.l: But all is well again, and must exalt
Thy truer joys by finding us both live,
And knit into a peace no time can violate,

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Let me salute the example of chaste honour;
Sister I now must call thee, and shall glory
To own that title by Jacintha's love.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Lady
sp.l: All blessings crown your wishes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I have a heart to wish you joys.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: They will be all a debt
To your noble care of us, master confident.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: One of my servants but not yet discharged.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You come to turn and wind this lady's fancy
With your wit now, but your devices fadge not,
It is three minutes since she was disposed of,
And though my stock of brain will not reach, to
Make a large jointure of so many hundred
Sonnets per annum, and rare elegies,
Some fresh, and some that ha' slain 7. years pickled,
In other languages: yet she'll be content
With a less witty fortune, my estate sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Tis happiness enough for me
To snuff your marriage taper, whose bright shine
shall put out the world's eye.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Spare, spare your fancies.
But I'll not now arraign you, if you mean
To have me, know me again, chaffer some wit
Away for honesty, I conceal your shame,

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: There's hope then of your pardon, when I rise
From what has justly forfeited my name,
To show the world your childing is not lost,
Your lordship will not be ashamed again
To own me for your servant.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I shall be a glad witness and admirer.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Will't please you gentlemen to have a song.
Sir solitary, and my lady are at it, he is grown
The most jovial gentleman — hark.

sp.speaker: La. Pl.
sp.l: Welcome welcome, again to thy wits.
This is a holy day.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.l: I'll have no plots, nor melancholy fits
But merrily pass the time away:
They are mad, that are sad.

sp.speaker: La. Pl.
sp.l: Be ruled by me;
And none shall be so merry as we.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.l: The kitchen shall catch cold no more.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'll have no key to the buttery door,

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: The fiddlers shall sing,
The house shall ring,
And the world shall see.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: What a merry couple.
Merry couple.
Couple, couple,
We will be.

div.stage: Enter sir solitary, and his lady.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: We are new married gentlemen, I must
Invite your lordship for my guest. Your tunes
Are melancholy. Welcome home my wand'ring nephew;
you shall be welcome too, sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'm your servant.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: When shall we dance Jacintha?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Sure this humour
Is very young, pray madam is he serious?
Is there no plot in this?

sp.speaker: La. Pl.
sp.l: Beyond my hope
He is recovered sir, and I must stand to't,
And turn a miracle, a lady housewife.

sp.speaker: Sir Sol.
sp.l: No more, lest with the joy I run into
A madness worse, than melancholy, you tell
Me wonders: bless my senses. And shall we dance?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I am for any mirth, the day requires it,
In which love too long blind hath found his eyes,
And leads the way to his own paradise.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Praise a fair day at night the proverb says,
And 'tis the evening that must crown all plays.
For although writers may be first allowed,
To speak themselves, their judgements are too proud
That waving all authority beside
Think 'tis enough when they are satisfied,
We must appeal to you, unless you smile
We have but cherished vain hopes all this while,
But if you like, by this we shall best prove it,
You'll follow the example, if you love it.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
